description: A long time ago, I explored the Debert River and posted a trailpeak post about it.  Long storu short is that I hiked along ways to see some small falls...nothing high like most of the rivers flowing on the south side of the cobequid hills.   Fast forward a few years and I am still haunted by the river and potential fall that I may have missed.  The old map mention a fall of about 35 ft in an area just downstream of a logging road bridge.  so its an easy hike...no bushwack involved.  I was in the area exploring the Folly river and decided to drop in to the Debert river to see that potential fall.I parked around N45° 32' 01.1" W63° 26' 29.2"", and headed for the bridge.  I followed the river downstream.  A small 5ft fall is just downstream of the bridge.  Soon after you enter a mini gorge like setting.  the river here has carved its path through sheer rock walls.  On the downstream end, I could see remnants of rock walls.  the tallest fall in this area is a only a few feet so disappointing in that aspect but the gorge makes it up for scenery.  So the conclusion here is the old map were describing a fall that was probably only present when a dam was constructed along this part of the river...my new topo map actually have a small dam icon at this location!  BTW the best fall to see on Debert is at; N45° 30' 52.8" W63° 26' 22.5" or on a tributary (at time of high water only)  at N45° 29' 46.3" W63° 26' 56.8".
directions: In Belmont. Take Belmont Rd heading north.  continue straight on Upper Belmont Rd and turn right at Y intersection at; N45° 30' 13.2" W63° 23' 12.2".  continue heading west until you drive down a hill and see a bridge on your left; N45° 32' 01.1" W63° 26' 29.2"
title: Debert River Upper Fall and gorge
